annotation.spannedText: Immunisation can prevent serious medical complications

classMention.mentionClass: Immunisation can prevent serious medical complications

annotation.spannedText: For children who have not had chickenpox, the vaccine can help protect them against serious complications associated with chickenpox and protect them from developing shingles later in life

classMention.mentionClass: For children who have not had chickenpox, the vaccine can help protect them against serious complications associated with chickenpox and protect them from developing shingles later in life

annotation.spannedText: Immunised children who get chickenpox generally have a much milder form of the disease. They have fewer skin lesions, a lower fever and recover more quickly

classMention.mentionClass: Immunised children who get chickenpox generally have a much milder form of the disease. They have fewer skin lesions, a lower fever and recover more quickly

annotation.spannedText: two doses of chickenpox vaccine in children provides increased protection and reduces the risk of chickenpox occurring at a later time

classMention.mentionClass: two doses of chickenpox vaccine in children provides increased protection and reduces the risk of chickenpox occurring at a later time

annotation.spannedText: If you are not immune during your pregnancy, you should avoid contact with people who have known cases of chickenpox

classMention.mentionClass: If you are not immune during your pregnancy, you should avoid contact with people who have known cases of chickenpox

annotation.spannedText: Contact your doctor, midwife or hospital as soon as possible if you are exposed to anyone with chickenpox

classMention.mentionClass: Contact your doctor, midwife or hospital as soon as possible if you are exposed to anyone with chickenpox

annotation.spannedText: The chickenpox vaccine is effective and safe, but all medications can have unwanted side effects

classMention.mentionClass: The chickenpox vaccine is effective and safe, but all medications can have unwanted side effects

annotation.spannedText: Common side effects following immunisation are usually mild and temporary (occurring in the first few days after vaccination)

classMention.mentionClass: Common side effects following immunisation are usually mild and temporary (occurring in the first few days after vaccination)

annotation.spannedText: It is also important to seek medical advice if you (or your child) are unwell, as this may be due to other illness, rather than because of the immunisation

classMention.mentionClass: It is also important to seek medical advice if you (or your child) are unwell, as this may be due to other illness, rather than because of the immunisation

annotation.spannedText: If the side effect following immunisation is unexpected, persistent or severe, or if you are worried about yourself or your child’s condition after immunisation, see your doctor or immunisation nurse as soon as possible or go directly to a hospital

classMention.mentionClass: If the side effect following immunisation is unexpected, persistent or severe, or if you are worried about yourself or your child’s condition after immunisation, see your doctor or immunisation nurse as soon as possible or go directly to a hospital

annotation.spannedText: There is a very small risk of a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to any vaccine

classMention.mentionClass: There is a very small risk of a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to any vaccine

annotation.spannedText: you are advised to stay at the clinic or medical surgery for at least 15 minutes following immunisation in case further treatment is required

classMention.mentionClass: you are advised to stay at the clinic or medical surgery for at least 15 minutes following immunisation in case further treatment is required

annotation.spannedText: Talk to your doctor or immunisation provider if you think you or someone in your care has health, age, lifestyle or occupation factors that could mean immunisation is necessary

classMention.mentionClass: Talk to your doctor or immunisation provider if you think you or someone in your care has health, age, lifestyle or occupation factors that could mean immunisation is necessary
